bibl.title: Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiuro v. United States. Response.

div1.p: In the District Court of the United States, for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the matter of the Deportation of Albert H. Young and B.K. Sugiura. } No. Brief.
The Rule.
The order of this brief will be to take up the rule of procedure first and afterwards the evidence only in so far as it bears on the rule.

The matter for consideration in this case seems to us to be res adjudicata until the case of In Re Unlawful Dentention of Mullah Singh and Seventy-two other Hindu Aliens, Case No. 2532, has been reversed by the Supreme Court. In that case the court says:
"The jurisdiction of the court is limited to ascertaining whether the pertitioners were denied a hearing."
And the Court cites to sustain the proposition the following:
The Court further says:

"A hearing having been accorded, the court is precluded from a re-examination of the issue presented, merely because it is contended that the conclusion of the immigration officers, based upon the testimony presented, was wrong."
The Court's decision is borne out by the reasoning and the exact language of our Supreme Court cases. Thus, in Chin Yow v. United States, 52 L.Ed. 369, the Court says:

"But unless and until it is proved to the satisfaction of the judge that a hearing properly so called was denied, the merits of the case are not open, and, we may add the denial of a hearing cannot be establsihed by proving that the decision was wrong."
And in the case of De Bruler v. Gallo, 184 Fed. 566, at page 569, that court follows the reasoning of this court, saying at 569,

"The contention being that the only question then properly before the court was whether or not the appellee had been given a fair hearing by the officers of the Department of Commerce and Labor upon the order to show cause why she should not be deported to the country from which she came. The position of the government in this respect must be sustained."
Again the court states the rule in another way in United States vs. Ju Toy, 49 L. Ed. 1040, 1043, where it says in giving the ruling in Lem Moon Sing vs. U.S. 39 L.Ed. 1082:

"Where the petitioner for habeas corpus alleged facts which, if true, gave him a right to enter and remain in the country, it was held that the decision of the collector was final as to whether or not he belonged to the privileged class."
Again, Chief Justice Holmes states a the rule in a case in which a writ of habeas corpus was allowed. Thus he says in the case of Chin Yow vs. United States, 52 L. Ed. 369:

"Of course, if the writ is granted, the first issue to be tried is the truth of the allegations last mentioned. If the petitioner was not denied a fair opportunity to produce the evidence that he desired, or a fair though summary hearing, the case can proceed no farther. Those facts are the foundation of the jurisdiction of the district court, if it has any jurisdiction at all. It must not 2
be supposed that the mere allegation of the facts opens the merits of the case, whether those facts are proved or not. And, by way of caution, we may add the jurisdiction would not be established simply by proving that the commissioner and the Department of Commerce and Labor did not accept certain sworn statements as true, even though no contrary or impeaching testimony was adduced."
Reason of the Rule.

The reason of this rule is that the determination as to the rights of aliens to remain in or be exvluded from the United States is one within the jurisdiction of Congress alone. It belongs to the political determinant department of the government alone and the final determination as to who shall be entitled to enter the United States may be entrusted to Congress to executive officers. (See a statement of the reason of the rule in the case of Lem Moon Sing vs. U.S., 39 L.Ed. 1084 in last paragraph of first column of page; and also see the same reason of the rule laid down in U.S. vs. Ju Toy, 49 L. Ed. 1043 last part of page). The counts have to none right to interfere than they wared if these aliens were in their own country petitioners admission to Courts.
Part of Immigration Act Involved.

These two aliens are being deported under that portion of Section 3 as mended by the Act of March 26, 1910, which provides that "any alien ***********who in any ways assists, protects or promises to protect from arrest, any prostitute, shall be deemed to be unlawfully within the United States and shall be deported in the manner provided by Sections 20 and 21 of this Act." Section 20 provides that any alien who shall enter the United States in violation of law, etc., shall upon the warrant of the Secretary of Labor, be taken into custody 3
and deported to the country whence he came. The rules of the Department, Subdivision 4(a), provide that upon receipt of a warrant of arrest, the alien shall be taken before an immigration officer and granted a hearing to enable him to show cause why he should not be deported; Subdivision (b) provides that he may inspect the warrant and examine the evidence from which it was issued and, at such stage of the proceedings as the officer before whom the hearing is held shall deem proper, be apprized that he may be represented by counsel; Subdivision (c) provides that at the close of the hearing a full record shall be forwarded to the bureau, together with any written arguments submitted by counsel and recommendations of the examining officer as to whether a warrant for deportation shall issue.
The Proceeding And Evidence in this Case.
In acoordance with these instructions a warrant was issued which was marked Exhibit "A" and will be found in the record after the testimony of Shotaro Washio.

On this warrant, in the manner provided by the rules, a hearing was had on November 3, 1913, and the two aliens, Young and Sugiura, were presented by counsel; after the testimony, including the brief of the attorney R.W. McClelland, was sent back to the Secretary of Labor. The statement of Shotaro Washio shows that Young and Sugiura knowingly assisted a prostitute (see page 1 of testimony of Shotaro Washio which is in the following language:

Q. Are you the same Shotaro Washio that testified in the 4
trial of Albert H. Young and B.K. Sugiura for transporting a girl named Hana Saito from Seattle to San Francisco? A. Yes.
Q. Did they assist you in taking her to San Francisco? A. Yes.
Q. What was that woman's occupation? A. That that time or after she got there.

Q. Before she left San Francisco to come here and after she returned to San Francisco? A. Prior to her departure from San Francisco she was sick and didn't do anything and after her return to Frisco she was a prostitute.
Q. Did Mr. Young and Sugiura know what her character was then they helped you to take her to San Francisco? A. Yes.
Q. How did they know it? A. I told them.
Q. Did you tell both of them or only one? a. I told Sugiura and whether he told Young or not I don't know.).
Also the testimony of Hana Saito (page 2 of her testimony) is to the same effect. Thus note the following language thereof:
Q. Did you at any time prior to your departure from Seattle for San Francisco tell Young and Sugiura or either of them that you had formerly practiced prostitution at the house at 1020 Stockton St.?

A. No, but Sugiura said while we were on board the ship that they would take me back to the house where I had been practicing prostitution before. They knew I had been a prostitute because Washio told them.
Q. Do you know who purchased your transportation to San Francisco?
A. Young and Sugiura did. They bought tickets on a boat sailing earlier and took me to the ticket office to get the tickets cancelled.
Q. Do you know if they recieved any money for taking you to San Francisco?
A. I heard later that they got $250.00 from Ito and Umeda.

The testimony further shows that Young and Sugiura promised to protect a prostitute from arrest (See the 5
testimony of Hana Saito on page 1 thereof which is as follows:

"Young said they were going to put me into jail and I thought I was arrested because Saito and I ran away from San Francisco. I asked if they were from the Immigration office at San Francisco or from the police and Young said they were from the police; I asked him if he had anything to do with the Immigration Office and he said 'If you don't come with us you will be turned over to the Immigration officers.'")
Again see the testimony of K. Ito on page 2 and 3 thereof which is as follows:

Q. What else did Young, Sugiura or Washio say at that time? A. Young and Sugiura said the agreement with Washio was to pay them $800 for bringing the girl down here but that things didn't go just right so they were willing to settle and take $400 and wanted me to pay them that. Sugiura said he had passed as an interpreter and that Young had passed as an Immigration officer and the woman believed them came without much trouble. Young and Sugiura told me it was worth $800 to take the chances of bringing this woman here to a house of prostitution and that they wanted their mnoney. They told me later that they had been to see Mr. Gardner of the Immigration office and had fixed things with him so there would be no trouble but that we must come through with the money to them. Young and Sugiura and went to the Imperial hotel, Washio and Hana stayed in my house. The next day, I think it was, Umeda and I were sent for by Young and Sugiura went over their agreement with Washio and said they couldn't wait for their money and must getback to Seattle and that Umeda and I must raise the money for them. Later in the day Young and Sugiura came to my house Umeda was present also and there I paid them $200 and later I paid them $50 more.
Application of Test to this Case.

This is sufficient to show that there was a sointilla of evidence for the immigration authorities and this under the law if sufficient. But there seems to be more than that. The stories of Young and Sugiura are not as probable as those of the government witnesses. 6
We do not, however, enter into this case under the rules as laid down by our Supreme Court and Judge Neterer in this district. The only question for consideration is whether a hearing was denied. There can be no pretense that this was done because Attorney McClelland represented the aliens before the immigration officer and sent a brief back to Washington (see his brief and also notice on page 6 of his brief at the point beginning at line 9 and ending at line 16 where he takes up the testimony and argues on it). Now he says that the testimony was not comptenet. Before the immigration authorities he did not object to the admission of any of these affidavits (see page 5 of the testimony of Sugiura wehre the testimony was offered without objection and see the examination of McClelland wehre he examines as to these various statements). Again it will be observed that McClelland, on behalf of the aliens, put in a lot of exparty affidavits which would be no more admissible than those of the government; but if the court was reviewing a lower court, he could not reverse it if the court let in testimony when there was no objection made to it, and if a court lets in such testimony, it is acting within its jurisdiction to consider the testimony after admitted. So this is bound to be considered as fair testimony and Mr. McClelland, the attorney for the aliens, reviews poritons of it in his brief. The inspection officers were fair. They allowed Mr. McClelland to have as much latitude as themseleves in putting in testimony and there is no showing in the record that the officers refused to allow him to put in any testimony on behalf of 7
his clients.
Meaning of the Word "Assists".

The word "assists" as used in this statute applies to cases where the prostitutes are assisted in the promotion of the practice or business of prostitution, but not cases where prostitutes may be given assistance which is in no way connected with the promotion or forwarding of said unlawful business (See the opinion of the solicitor of the Department of Labor which is attached to the next last page and made a part of this brief). But suppose the attorney will say that the consturction of the statute is for the Court Congress and not for the Immigration officers. Under the rule stated above and the reasons given therefor we can not agree with counsel because language in the Lem Moon Sing case seems to seetle this question. There the court says (39 L. Ed. 1085) that " it is contended that if an alien is entitled by law or treaty to enter this country and is nevertheless excluded by immigration officers, the latter exceed their jurisdiction and their action should be reviewed by the courts", but that such a contention cannot be sustained and that if it were, it would bring into the courts every case of an alien claiming the right to come into the United States under some law or treaty who was prevented from doing so by the executive branch of the government.

It is clear that the construction of the law given by the immigration authorities should control the court because if they have jurisdiction to enforce the law and to pass rules and regulations for the enforcement 8
thereof, they certainly have jurisdiction to interpret the law and Congress certainly intended this to be the case because otherwise the immigration laws would not be uniform through the United States. The Secretary of Labor enforces these laws and the meaning that he places on them is to be followed by the immigration officers all over the United States. If the courts could interpret the law, the District Courts and Circuit Courts of Appeal of the various districts would have different rules for admission and a man that would be excluded by the law as interpreted in New York City would probably be admitted in Seattle, Washington, so there would be no uniformity of the law over the United States. Suppose a lower court says a statute means one thing and an upper couert says it means another, would the lower court be without jurisdiction in interpreting the meaning of the statute? If it interpreted the statute wrong, would it be lacking in jurisdiction?

Here the immigration authorities have a hearing and from the evidence introduced at this hearing the immigrants should be deported according to their construction of the law. Does any one maintain that in doing this they act outside of their jurisdiction? If so, there are many points in the immigration laws where the courts would doubtless differ form the immigration authorities as to the construction of the law.

The only matter for this court to consider is whther these aliens who are being deported have been denied a hearing, and it seems to us that it is clear that 9
they have not.
div1.ab: Respectfully submitted, Clay Allen United States Attorney. G.P. Fishburne Assistant United States Attorney.
div1.p: See also Frick v. Seemis 195 Fed 693 & Williams v. U.S. 186 Fed 479 cases cited at argument.
Department of Labor Office of the Solicitor
Jule 9, 1913
In RE the meaning and effect of the word "assist" as used in section 3 of the Immigration Act of 1907, as amended March 26, 1910.
I am requested to express an opinion as to the meaning of that portion of section 3 of the Immigration Act of March 26, 1910, (36 Stat. 264) which reads as follows:

"that any alien who in any way assists, protects, or promises to protect from arrest any prostitute, shall be deemed to be unlawfully within the United States ans shall be deported in the manner provided by sections twenty and twenty-one of this Act".

The question is raised in connection with the case of Louis Gassounis, alias Leoieli Kassumis. It appears from the papers submitted that Gassounis, an alien and a Greek by birth, lived for over six years in Oakland, California, where he owned half interest in two barber shops, yielding him an icome of about $125 per month. He bore a good reputation for honesty, morality, and integrity until he met a young woman named Maida Johnson. He made a date with her, and the result was one or more acts of sexual intercourse between them. Thereafter he rented a room and lived with the woman as his wife. Then she insisted on becoming an inmate of a house of prostitution. He tried to persuade her not to take up such a life, but she insisted, and told him she would not speak to him unless he did what he could to secure her a place in a house of prostitution. Then, uoting form a statment signed by Judge Ellsworth and District Attorney Donahue, "He thereupon went to the house of a woman named Dupont and secured a place for the girl there. She was there for some days and then left and again asked the defendant to secure a place for her. He went out the second time and secured another place for her in the house of Julia Baker, where she stayed for some ten or twelve days, and where he came to visit her, remaining, according to his own admission, all night on five or six occasions."
He was arrested charged with the violation of a state statute known as the "Pandering Law", convicted and sentenced to two years in the State Penitentiary.

In November last, shortly after he had begun to serve his term in the State prison, the Acting Secretary of Commerce and Labor issued a warrant for his arrest on the ground that he was unlawfully in the United States, being an alien found receiving, sharing in or deriving benefit from the earnings of a prostitute. The record contained no evidence to support such a charge and the Acting Secretary of Labor, under date of June 12, 1913, cancelled the warrant.
In reference to this action the Commissioner of Immigration at San Francisco wrote the Commissioner-General of Immigration under date of June 20, as follows:

"When this case was presented to the Bureau in my letter of November 5th, 1912, the offense with which the man was charged was indicated, and was that he had been convicted for a violation of the State Law of Pandering. It was not contended that he received, shared in, or derived any benefit form this woman's earnings, but it would seem that he assisted and protected her, which is a part of the same section. In other words assisting and protecting a prositute is a violation of the Immigration Act, and there is evidence that this alien assisted a prostitute and protected her to the extent of placing her in an immoral house, and was convicted under the State Law of Pandering. Therefore it would seem that assisting and protecting a prositute under the Immigration Law has as its equivalent the Pandering Act of the State of California."

The law which is to be contrued in connection with this particular case is very awkwardly worded. It says "that any alien who in anuyway assists, protects, or promises to protect from arrest any prostitute, shall be deemed to be unlawfully within the United States." Was it the intention of Congress that the word "assists" should be given effect only in connection with the word "arrest"? If so, the statute would have to be construed as though it read "any alien who in any way assists from arrest any prostitute". Besided being poor English, such a construction would practically eliminate the word "assists" from the statute for the expression "protects from arrest" is just as broad as the expression "assists from arrest".

Such a construction would not, I am sure, give effect to the plain intention of Congress. It would permit prostitutes to receive and profit by the assistance of aliens and to carry on and extend the immoral practices against which the section in question is aimed. The immigration authorities could exercise no restraining or preventive power over aliens rendering such assistance. There is no other provision of law that would apply to all such cases. I cannot think that Congress used the word "assists" merely as a qualification of the words "from arrest".

The only other view which occurs to me is that the word "assists" is to be given effect in connection with the words "any prostitute". According to this view, the statute would have to be constured as though it read "any alien who in any ways assists any prostitute". This view is open to the objection that, literally, it would subject to deportation any alien who might try to save a fallen woman by taking care of her and assisting her to obtain honorable employment, and would apply to aliens connected with Christian Missions, the Salvation Army, and other like organizations whose activities in assiting prostitutes are most praiseworthy.
But I do not think it necessary to give the statute such a literal construction.

It is fundamental law that the intent of the legislature must be gathered from the language used, but that, in case of ambiguity, particular words must be so construed as to give a reasonable and sensible effect to the statute as a whole.
Sutherland on Statutory Consturction (Vol.2, p. 913) quotes from the case of People vs. Chicago, 1`52 Ill. 546-552 as follows:

"When the literal enforcement of a statute would result in great inconvenience and cause great injustice, and lead to consequences which are absurd and which the legislature could not have contemplated, the courts are bound to presume that such consequences were not intended, and adopt a construction which will promote the ends of justice and avoid the absurdity."
X See also the case of Holy Trinity vs. U.S., 143 U.S. 457.

In the chapter on statutory construction in volume 1 of the Federal Statutes Annotated at page LXXVLLL, it is stated, "It has been laid down again and again that "a thing which is within the intention of a statute is as much within the statute as if it were within the letter; and a thing whihc is within the letter of the statute is not within the statute unless it is within the intention of the makers!"

A careful reading of the entire Immigration Law and a consideration of its general purpose and the mischief to be supressed, lead to the conclusion that Congress intended that the word "assists" should be given a broader application that a mere qualification of the words "from arrest"; that it should apply to cases where prostitutes are assisted in the promotion of the practice or business of prostitution, but not to cases where prostitutes may be given assistance which is in no way connected with the practice or business of prostitution or assistance which, on the other hand, may be calculated to suppress or discourage such practice or business.

If the Secretary finds the record in the case of Mr. Gassounis that the alien assisted a prostitute in the sense indicated in this opinion, I have to advise that the law justified the deportation of such alien.
The Honorable, The Secretary of Labor. M-k No. 53,510/337
July 19th, 1913.
Respectfully furnished to all Commissioners of Immigration and Inspectors in Charge of Districrts, for their information and guidance in handling cases of this class.
Mc Copy D
